Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Cellular Network Services in Peril: A Perspective on Control-Plane and Data-Plane Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The cellular network is the largest wireless infrastructure deployed today. It offers users mobile Internet access and carrier-grade voice service. Each such service (e.g., data or voice) typically involves operations on both data and control planes. The former transfers service content to users, whereas the latter performs control functions of service instantiation, maintenance, update, and termination. Securing control and data planes is thus critical to mobile network service. Different from the Internet built upon the single best-effort delivery, the fourth-generation (4G) mobile network supports diversified service models. It not only provides multiple priorities within the network (e.g., voice has higher priority than data), but also carries control and data over different radio channels. Consequently, given a service (e.g., voice, video, or messaging), its control-plane and data-plane operations open new venues for security research. This project aims to study both planes in 4G networks from the security perspective. The success of this research will not only protect the trillion-dollar market of mobile voice for billions of smartphone users, but also safeguard the mobile Internet access from attacks initiated by malicious calls. The proposed activity may influence the upcoming 5G technology standardization and train a new generation of engineers and students.

The proposed research has two main thrusts. One is the insecurity analysis of 4G network services. This project examines the control and data planes and their coordination. It conducts thorough theoretical analysis to uncover all potential vulnerabilities, explores novel attacks, and empirically validates those practical threats. The other is to propose defenses to secure both planes from such threats. The solution calls for concerted efforts between the network and the user, and between hardware and software. This project seeks to make three contributions: (1) Systematic disclosure of insecurity on the control-plane and data-plane operations: Both incur new breaches that current defense measures fail to protect; (2) Identification of diverse root causes: Mobile standards stipulate loose regulations, whereas device software and hardware assume protection from each other. As both planes become more accessible to smartphones, no new protection mechanisms are in place. (3) Solution that secures both control-plane and data-plane operations: It adds protection at both hardware and software at mobile devices, and inside the network infrastructure. It further leverages device capabilities while preserving flexible network services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has investigated emerging security issues in 4G voice and messaging services, which are used by billions of mobile users on their daily basis. Each such service (e.g., voice or messaging) typically involves operations on both data and control planes. The former transfers service content to users, whereas the latter performs control functions of service instantiation, maintenance, update, and termination. The service evolution in 4G networks adopts new control-plane and data-plane operations and thus opens new venues for security research. Throughout this project, we have successfully demonstrated new vulnerabilities in commerical 4G networks, pinpointed their root causes, devised defense solutions, and shed light on securing evolving cellular network technologies.

We summarize our main outcomes in two aspects.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, we conducted security analysis of four key voice and messaging technologies: voice over LTE (VoLTE), circuit-switching fallback (CSFB), WiFi Calling and 4G SMS over IP. We have examined their control and data planes, as well as their coordination and uncovered new vulnerabilities that stem from improper standard designs, device implementation issues and operation slips. We have devised multiple novel attacks, and empirically validated those proof-of-concept attacks in US carriers. Finally, we have proposed solutions that secures both control-plane and data-plane operations, through adding protection at both the hardware and software at mobile devices, as well as on the network side. We have further leveraged the device’s power while preserving flexible service support. Our results have resulted in 6 papers: CCS’15, CNS’15, CCS’16, HotMobile’16, CNS’18 and MobiCom’18.

Broader Impacts:  The results of this project not only protect mobile voice and messaging services used by billions of smartphone users, but also safeguard the mobile Internet access from attacks initiated by malicious calls. The immediate adoption of our research results by US carriers has quickly fixed these vulnerabilities and protected US carriers and their mobile users from real threats (e.g., free data access attacks and spoofing attacks) and have addressed big social concerns. Lessons learned from this project also benefit network security in face of emerging technologies. This project helps training a new generation of students and workforce in cybersecurity, information and communication technology.
